comment: When having the option, it is generally better to capture TOWARD the center of the board. Hence bxc6 is preferred. In addition, this would give black an excellent post for his queen bishop on a6. Notice that black's queen bishop doesn't even move this game! If white does proper defence, this lack of post for thie bishop could've meant a loss for black.
reasoning: The comment accurately explains that the move bxc6 was a mistake because it weakened the dark squares in the center and allowed white to potentially exploit this by targeting the queen bishop and gaining control over the center.

comment: Remember: Using ALL of your chessmen is always more effective. White could've played the correct O-O, and after Rad1, Rfe1, ALL of his pieces would be active, while black has a hemmed in light-squared bishop. White would have real chances to save his game, despite being a pawn minus. Instead white gives up his b-pawn for free.
reasoning: The comment explains the mistake made by the player because it highlights the strategic disadvantage of the move, which limits the activity of White's pieces and gives Black a better position.
